noun.description: A shape produced by a curve that bends around and crosses itself.
A structure, series, or process, the end of which is connected to the beginning.

verb.description: Form (something) into a loop or loops; encircle.
examples: she looped her arms around his neck

phrases: So, if you haven't got an invite by now, you're out of the loop.
Currently that's the scoop we've got for you - we'll keep you in the loop about new information as it becomes available to us.
Gossip isn't always vicious, sometimes it's just informative and keeps you in the loop.
I'm not completely out of the loop, though, I must confess.
You know you're out of the loop when you get the announcement of the new baby and you didn't know your friend was even in a relationship.
origin: Late Middle English: of unknown origin; compare with Scottish Gaelic lùb loop, bend.
